entry.title: October 2 Employee Central Live Session
entry.content:
Thank you to everyone who attended the Employee Central Live Session on October 2. 

This session was the second part of the five-day Employee Central Workshop series, which focuses on activating the core functions of Employee Central from scratch. 

Here's a brief summary of Day 2â€”Configuring Foundation Objects:

  • The Foundation Objects Configuration Workbook serves as a baseline for capturing customer requirements related to Foundation Objects
  • The tools used for configuring XML-based Foundation Objects are:
    • Corporate Data Models
    • Manage Organization Pay and Job Structures
    • Import Foundation Data
  • The tools used for configuring MDF-based Foundation Objects are:
    • Configure Object Definition
    • Manage Data, 
    • Import and Export Data
  • Composite Associations are used to create a parent-child relationship
  • Valid-When Associations are used to establish hierarchy levels in the organization structure
  • The order of data import depends on the associations configured between the objects.

You can find the presentation when you log in to https://learning.sap.com. Go to My Learning > Live Sessions. 

Thank you.

entry.title: October 1 Employee Central Live Session
entry.content:
Thank you to everyone who attended the Employee Central Live Session on October 1. 

This session was part of the 5-day series Employee Central Workshop which focuses on activating the core functions of Employee Central from scratch. 

Here's a brief summary of Day 1- Provisioning and Other Initial Configurations:

  • The list of provisioning settings to enable Employee Central's core functionality is listed in the Implementing Employee Central - Basic Settings section
  • A super admin is created in provisioning to create a security administrator who will then manage the RBP groups and roles
  • The set of standard picklists called "Master Picklist" must be uploaded to support the fields that have picklist references
  • The four data models used in Employee Central must be uploaded in this order:
    • Corporate Data Model
    • Country-specific Corporate Data Model
    • Succession Data Model
    • Country-specific Succession Data Model

You can find the presentation when you log in to https://learning.sap.com. Go to My Learning > Live Sessions. 

Thank you.

entry.title: From Penalty to Power Play: Why Identity Management Is Key to Better Customer Experiences
entry.content:
A few weeks ago, a friend bought tickets to a hockey game and wanted to transfer them to me. Like many people, we went with the quickest workaroundâ€”she shared her login credentials so I could access the tickets. But what should have been a simple process turned into several days of password resets, missed messages, and back-and-forth. By the time I finally got into her account, the tickets were gone. She had attempted to transfer them during the delay, but amid the confusion and technical issues, I never actually received them. If I had been able to log in right away, I could have just downloaded them directly. But the access issues created confusion, and without any clear support from the platform, we ended up losing the ticketsâ€”and missing the game.

It was a simple plan that fell apart because of something as basic as account access.

This experience is a small example of a much larger issue in digital commerce: the friction that arises when identity management isnâ€™t built with the customer in mind. Itâ€™s easy to overlook, but poor identity experiences lead directly to lost opportunitiesâ€”not just for consumers, but for the businesses trying to reach them.

 

Identity Friction = Lost Revenue

In todayâ€™s commerce landscape, customer expectations are sky-high. If a login process is confusing, if an account is hard to access, or if personalization feels offâ€”people walk away. And often, they donâ€™t come back.

Poor identity experiences hurt businesses in more ways than one:

  • They interrupt the buying journey. Whether itâ€™s a login loop, a forgotten password, or a complicated checkout flow, friction at these key points drives abandonment.
  • They block personalization. When customer data is fragmented across systems, itâ€™s hard to deliver the tailored experiences that todayâ€™s buyers expect.
  • They erode trust. Without clear consent management and transparency, customers hesitate to share informationâ€”or stop engaging entirely.
  • They slow down growth. Outdated systems and homegrown solutions often canâ€™t keep up with omnichannel strategies or evolving compliance needs.

For a deeper dive into how SAP CIAM can help reduce identity friction, join us at SAP TechEd on November 6 for a dedicated CIAM security session. Register here to secure your spot and learn more.

 

Where SAP CIAM + Commerce Cloud Make the Difference

Customer Identity and Access Management (CIAM) helps solve these challenges by making identity work for the customerâ€”not against them. When integrated into your commerce ecosystem, CIAM doesn't just handle sign-insâ€”it actively supports better customer relationships and business outcomes.

Hereâ€™s how:

  • It reduces friction at every stageâ€”from anonymous browsing to account creation to repeat purchases. The experience becomes smoother, simpler, and more secure.
  • It improves conversion by enabling personalized, real-time engagement without relying on clunky data handoffs or third-party cookies.
  • It builds trust by giving customers control over their data, preferences, and permissionsâ€”while helping businesses stay compliant across regions.
  • It supports scale by integrating identity across every digital touchpoint, enabling consistent experiences on web, mobile, in-store, and beyond.

In short, CIAM allows businesses to move away from fragmented, frustrating interactions and toward a unified customer experience that feels intuitive, safe, and relevantâ€”every time. To hear firsthand how SAP customers are achieving this with SAP CIAM and Commerce Cloud, join us at SAP Connect in Las Vegas on October 8. Register here to attend.

 

The Takeaway

In commerce, moments of friction are more than just annoyancesâ€”theyâ€™re missed opportunities. Whether itâ€™s lost hockey tickets or lost revenue, the cause is often the same: a broken identity experience.

Modern CIAM, especially when combined with a powerful commerce platform, turns identity into an asset. It streamlines the journey, protects the user, and empowers businesses to engage with clarity and confidence.

And the best part? It just worksâ€”so your customers donâ€™t have to. 

Learn more here.

entry.title: Re: confidential enterprise projects
entry.content:
Hello @tomlovelock 

Besides Chris's comments, restrict access to ETO/defence projects so that only users with a â€œusers assigned access basis can view them.

Follow this process below

Assign the project to an Authorisation Group in the Enterprise Project field.

In' Maintain Business Roles, ' set Restrictions â†’ Read to' Restricted' for the project apps, and specify the allowed Authorisation Group values for each role.

For highly sensitive work, set Confidential Project to true and keep a small, designated project team; only authorised roles and members will see it.

This concludes the process; there is no necessity for cost-center modifications. Conduct a test using two rolesâ€”one inclusive of the group value and the other excluding itâ€”and verify visibility.

Authoritative references

  • Maintain Business Role Restrictions â€“ how to restrict by fields (set Read to Restricted and keep values). 
  • SAP Help Portal-Identity and Access Management-How to Define Authorisations Based on Restrictions
  • Enterprise Project CDS (I_ENTERPRISEPROJECT) shows AuthorizationGroup and ConfidentialProject fields used for the controls above. SAP Business Accelerator Hub-I_EnterprisedProject(Basic)

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: SAP BTP Trial Establish Trust issue
entry.content:
Hello everyone.

I am currently trying to complete a mission on SAP.com using a trial account. I have created a new trial subaccount and added the SAP Cloud Identity Services. The service appears to be added successfully.

However, when I go to Security â†’ Trust Configuration and try to click Establish Trust, I keep getting an error message like the one in the screenshot.

I have already tried the following steps:

  1. Deleted and recreated the trial account.
  2. Added the Cloud Identity Service again.
  3. Created azure instead of amazon.
  4. Repeated the process several times, but the problem remained.

It seems that the subaccount cannot interact properly with IAS (possibly a problem with the tenant registry).

Could you please help me understand why my trial account cannot establish trust?

Thank you in advance for your help!

entry.title: SAP Build Apps Booster Fails at "Checking Custom Identity Provider" with Unexpected Internal Error
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I am trying to activate the SAP Build Apps booster in my SAP BTP trial global account. The process consistently fails at the "Check Prerequisites" step, specifically at "Checking Custom Identity Provider", with the following error message:

"We are sorry, but we have encountered an unexpected internal error. Please try again later."

As a result, subsequent checks including "Checking Entitlements" are skipped and the booster setup cannot complete.

  • I have clicked the Rerun button several times, but the error persists.

  • The trial account was created recently and I am following the standard booster activation steps.

  • Attached is a screenshot showing the error for additional context.

     

Has anyone else faced this issue recently or does anyone know a solution/workaround? Is this a backend issue on SAP's side? Any guidance from SAP support would be appreciated, as I'm unable to proceed with my SAP Build Apps trial.

Thank you in advance!
#btp

entry.title: Implementing a Dynamic YTD Filter Up to Yesterday in SAP Story
entry.content:
Hi all,

I want to set up a dynamic YTD filter in an SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) story that always goes up to the previous day. The goal is for the filter to automatically consider the current year, but have the end date update daily.

Important: On the first day of the month, the filter should show the last day of the previous month, not the current monthâ€™s first day

I tried to use the Offset  function for selecting the previous day but this didnt work when I try to Show YTD for the current year.

Best,

Moritz

entry.title: Customizing Your PDF with the Categories of Class A Invoices
entry.content:
Hello!  

In this blog, we will walk you through the steps of designing the new PDF templates using Adobe LiveCycle to remain compliant with R.G. NÂ° 5762/2025 and R.G. NÂ°5764/2025 for Argentina. 

If you carry out sales, work placements or provision of services in Argentina using print character M for VAT-registered taxpayers, according to resolution R.G. NÂ° 5762/2025 and R.G. NÂ°5764/2025, as of December 1, 2025, you must replace the existing class M invoices with the new categories of Class A invoices: 

Categories of Class A Invoices 

Description 

What you need to do 

Standard Class A 

For taxpayers meeting all fiscal and solvency requirements 

Nothing 

Class A with legend â€œOPERACIÃ“N SUJETA A RETENCIÃ“Nâ€ 

For taxpayers who do not meet certain requirements 

You design a new PDF template 

Class A with legend â€œPAGO EN CBU INFORMADAâ€ 

For taxpayers who may not meet solvency criteria, requiring payments to be made to a specific, declared bank account (CBU) 

You design a new PDF template 

Prerequisites: 

  • You haveâ€¯Adobe LiveCycle Designerâ€¯on your computer and know how to design forms with this tool.â€¯ 
  • You have assigned theâ€¯Extensibilityâ€¯(SAP_CORE_BC_EXT) authorization role for your user.â€¯ 

Procedure: 

1. Access theâ€¯Maintain Form Templatesâ€¯(F1434) app.  

2. Go to theâ€¯Predelivered Templatesâ€¯tab and search for the following PDF form:â€¯ 

Document Type: 

Print Char A, B, E 

Form Template Name: 

EDO_AR_PRINT 

Data Source: 

EDOC_AR_PRINT_SRV_03 

3. Open the form template and selectâ€¯Download.â€¯ 

4. Extract the downloaded ZIP file and open theâ€¯.xdpâ€¯file in theâ€¯Adobe Livecycle Desginer.â€¯ 

5. In theâ€¯Adobe LifeCycle Designer, choose theâ€¯Master Pagesâ€¯tab.â€¯â€¯ 

6. From theâ€¯Object Library, drag and drop a Text onto the PageType box of your PDF. (Note: We suggest placing the Text on the bottom left corner of the PageType box.)  

7. On the Hierarchy tab, select the new field (default name Text1) and open the context menu (right-click or press Shift+F10). Choose Rename, type Legenda, and press Enter.  

8. Edit the new Legenda text. Insert the respective text value: â€œPAGO EN CBU INFORMADAâ€ or â€œOPERACIÃ“N SUJETA A RETENCIÃ“Nâ€. 

9. On the Hierarchy tab, select the content field. 

10. After selecting the content field, open the Script Editor (default shortcut Ctrl+Shift+F5) and insert the following Javascript logic to configure Legenda field:  

if (this.resolveNode("sfHeader.content.var_PrintChar").rawValue == 'A' ) { 
  this.resolveNode("sfHeader.content.Legenda").presence = "visible"; 
} else { 
this.resolveNode("sfHeader.content.Legenda").presence = "hidden"; 
}

11. Save and name your template. 

12. Access theâ€¯Maintain Form Templatesâ€¯(F1434) app.â€¯

13. On theâ€¯Custom Templatesâ€¯tab, chooseâ€¯New. Create a custom template for your form by making the following settings:â€¯ 

  • Form Template Name: Enter a name for your form template.â€¯ 
  • Language: Select the language of your form template.â€¯ 
  • Select Form Template File: Upload the file that you've created inâ€¯Adobe LiveCycle Designer.â€¯ 
  • Data Source: EDOC_AR_PRINT_SRV_03â€¯ 
  • Form Type: Chooseâ€¯Standalone.â€¯ 

14. Save your form template.â€¯ 

15. In your configuration environment, use the search function to open theâ€¯Configure Printing Form for eInvoiceâ€¯(103277)â€¯configuration activity and assign your custom form template to the relevant eDocument type and branch.â€¯â€¯ 

And that's it!

You can now open the eDocument Cockpit and submit your document. The PDF form templates you created contain the new categories of Class A invoices for VAT-registered taxpayers. 

Was this post helpful? Leave a like (kudo) and share the content with your colleagues. Feel free to leave feedback, comments, or questions in the space below.    

For more information, go to Document and Reporting Compliance for Argentina on the SAP Help Portal and make sure to followâ€¯SAP Document and Reporting Compliance.    

 

Regards, 

JoÃ£o Pedro Braun Agnes & Pedro Brum

entry.title: Seeking Implementation Insight: Onboarding Compliance Forms,I-9, E-Verify
entry.content:
Weâ€™re implementing SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting + Onboarding with Employee Central as a mini-master (core HR remains PeopleSoft). We have high-volume hiring across disparate business groups and across a large swath of the United States.

I want to collect proven patterns and pitfalls from practitioners so our design is scalable, auditable, and maintainable. Iâ€™m especially interested in what worked in your implementation and what youâ€™d do differently.

 
1) Reverification tracking (expiring work authorization)

  • For populations onboarded in SuccessFactors, how are you tracking document expirations and reverification (jobs, alerts, tiles, reports)?

  • Whatâ€™s your operational cadence (owners, frequencies, escalations), and how do you reconcile with downstream HR (e.g., PeopleSoft) to avoid mismatches?

  • Any lessons on roles/permissions so teams see what they need without over-permissioning?

Examples welcome: sample alert configurations, job schedules, or a simple RACI for reverification.

2) Policy acknowledgements: unified vs. per-policy

  • Did you implement one consolidated â€œPolicy Acknowledgementâ€ or maintain separate acknowledgements (e.g., handbook, IT, confidentiality)?

  • What choice improved audits (clearer scope of consent, easier version proof), and how do you link policy content (tiles, attachments) to the signed acknowledgement?

  • Tips for keeping signatures auditable and documents fresh?

SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding

entry.title: S/4HANA API for A_JournalEntryItemBasic changes order of results if $select fields
entry.content:
When I query using the REST API the A_JournalEntryItemBasic resource of the API_JOURNALENTRYITEMBASIC_SRV service, if I change the list of fields to retrieve, using the $select parameter, then the order of the results change. Even if I add an $orderby !

For example, I expect that a GET request to this two URLs return the same record (same ID, same URI) but represented with a different set of fields. Because I'm passing `$top=1` so only the first result should be returned:

  1. GET https://sandbox.api.sap.com//s4hanacloud/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_JOURNALENTRYITEMBASIC_SRV/A_JournalEntryItemBasic?%24top=1&%24select=ID%2CLedger%2CLedgerName%2CSourceLedger%2CLedg
    erFiscalYear%2CControllingArea%2CControllingAreaName%2CCompanyCode%2CCompanyCodeName%2CGLAccount%2CGLAccountName&%24orderby=Ledger
  2. GET https://sandbox.api.sap.com//s4hanacloud/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_JOURNALENTRYITEMBASIC_SRV/A_JournalEntryItemBasic?%24top=1&%24select=WBSElement%2CWBSElementDescription%2CPartnerCo
    mpanyCode%2CPartnerCompanyCodeName%2CCostCtrActivityType%2CCostCtrActivityTypeName%2COrderID%2CLedger&%24orderby=Ledger

But two different URIs are returned. First:

{'__metadata': {'id': "https://sandbox.api.sap.com/s4hanacloud/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_JOURNALENTRYITEMBASIC_SRV/A_JournalEntryItemBasic('.1~0C.3~0L.4~2018.5~A000.7~1010.9~0000000001')",
  'uri': "https://sandbox.api.sap.com/s4hanacloud/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_JOURNALENTRYITEMBASIC_SRV/A_JournalEntryItemBasic('.1~0C.3~0L.4~2018.5~A000.7~1010.9~0000000001')",
  'type': 'API_JOURNALENTRYITEMBASIC_SRV.A_JournalEntryItemBasicType'},
 'ID': '.1~0C.3~0L.4~2018.5~A000.7~1010.9~0000000001',
 'Ledger': '0C',
 'LedgerName': 'Management Accounting',
 'SourceLedger': '0L',
 'LedgerFiscalYear': '2018',
 'ControllingArea': 'A000',
 'ControllingAreaName': 'Controlling Area A000',
 'CompanyCode': '1010',
 'CompanyCodeName': 'BestRun DE',
 'GLAccount': '1',
 'GLAccountName': 'Paybls Domestic'}

And second:

{'__metadata': {'id': "https://sandbox.api.sap.com/s4hanacloud/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_JOURNALENTRYITEMBASIC_SRV/A_JournalEntryItemBasic('.1~0C.71~.73~.75~.77~')",
  'uri': "https://sandbox.api.sap.com/s4hanacloud/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_JOURNALENTRYITEMBASIC_SRV/A_JournalEntryItemBasic('.1~0C.71~.73~.75~.77~')",
  'type': 'API_JOURNALENTRYITEMBASIC_SRV.A_JournalEntryItemBasicType'},
 'Ledger': '0C',
 'WBSElement': '',
 'WBSElementDescription': '',
 'PartnerCompanyCode': '',
 'PartnerCompanyCodeName': '',
 'CostCtrActivityType': '',
 'CostCtrActivityTypeName': '',
 'OrderID': ''}

The OData specification says:

Select System Query Option ($select): A data service URI with a $select System Query Option identifies the same set of entities as a URI without a $select query option; however, the presence of a $select query option specifies that a response from the data service SHOULD return a subset, as identified by the value of the $select query option, of the properties that would have been returned had the URI not included a $select query option.

What am I missing?

 

UPDATE:
Apparently what I take as a row ID is actually a GENERATED_ID : a special property name used in OData services to uniquely identify aggregated or grouped data records. When you request aggregated data in an OData service, a GENERATED_ID property is automatically created for each resulting group. This ID serves as a unique key for that aggregated record, allowing you to request the same aggregated data again by referencing this ID.

So now, I don't know how to identify rows and thus how to match two rows from different queries. Can I rely on the order of the results?

entry.title: Re: Purchase Requisitions in the project
entry.content:
Hello @kailas_goley2 

This can be accomplished using the standard Project System (PS) in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud by managing the grouping of purchase requisitions.

The aim is to create separate PRs for BOM components and locally procured components.

Recommended configuration

Divide the sources into separate parts.

Implement two networks or dedicated activities within the project:

  • Assign BOM components to Network A.
  • Assign the Direct/Local Procurement components to Network B.

Enable Collective Purchase Requisition behaviour for network and component requirements.

This instructs the system to create separate PR documents for each network or activity, rather than merging all items into one PR.

Assign materials accordingly

BOM items are classified under Network A, while local or direct items fall under Network B.

Result: The MRP/requirements run will generate one PR for the BOM and another PR for locally procured items, each with separate PR numbers, rather than a single PR containing multiple lines.

Useful SAP References

  • SAP Learning Network Customising): The Collective PReq determines for each network whether a single purchase requisition with multiple items is created or multiple purchase requisitions with a single item each. SAP Learning-Customising Networks
  • SAP KBA 2539346 â€“ Multiple Purchase Requisitions from Network Activity (explains default grouping behaviour and why multiple items often end up in one PR without collective settings. SAP Support Portal-2539346 - Multiple Purchase Requisitions from Network Activity

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Optimizing Accessibility for Visual Impairment
entry.content:
According to the World Health Organization (WHO), at least 2.2 billion people have a visual impairment, ranging from mild vision loss to difficulties perceiving details, light, or movement[1]. However, accessibility isnâ€™t just for people with permanent impairments. Inclusive design also benefits anyone dealing with everyday barriers, which can be situational or temporary impairments, like screen glare in the sun, eye strain after a long day, or simply forgetting their glasses.

A woman with a visual impairment smiles while holding a smartphone close to her face. Text reads: "2.2 Billion+ people worldwide have a visual impairment (WHO). SAP designs for those with vision impairments. Check out our tips for color contrast, text resizing and more!"

Design for Accessibility is Design for Everyone

When we design with accessibility in mind, weâ€™re not just checking a box, weâ€™re creating digital experiences that are easier to use for everyone. Making information more perceivable and tasks more achievable doesnâ€™t just help some users; it makes products better across the board.

5 tips to Optimize Accessibility for Those with Visual Impairments

Designing with empathy starts with understanding the broad spectrum of visual abilityâ€”from permanent impairments to situational challenges. To help you translate this understanding into tangible action, SAPâ€™s Accessibility Design Tools and the Inclusive Research Handbook offer a firm foundation. With these resources in mind, here are five tips to get you started:

1. Scalable Text and Components

  • Support scalable text and UI components without breaking layouts.
  • Ensure resizing is smooth without content overlap or truncation.
  • Why? When text or interface elements are too small or cannot be adjusted, users with visual impairments may have difficulty reading and using them effectively.

2. Color schemes

  • Use high-contrast color schemes and ensure sufficient contrast ratios for text and key UI elements.
  • Avoid relying on color alone to convey information.
  • Why? Low contrast can reduce the ability for users to distinguish interface elements and text.

3. Well-structured layouts

  • Design clean, well-structured layouts that adapt smoothly to smaller or magnified viewports, minimizing horizontal scrolling, and preserving hierarchy.
  • Why? Wide or cluttered layouts can overwhelm people with reduced visual fields or magnified views or those using magnification.

4. Testing

  • Test designs at various zoom levels to ensure readability and functionality remain intact.
  • Why? Users who rely on zooming or magnification tools may encounter distorted or broken interfaces if designs are not flexible and well-structured.

5. Spacing

  • Allow line height, letter spacing, and word spacing to adjust without cutting off text or breaking layouts.
  • Ensure readability when users apply custom spacing settings.
  • Why? Fixed text spacing can make it difficult for users with cognitive disabilities such as dyslexia to read text effectively.

How SAP Designs with Accessibility in Mind

Technology keeps changing, but our commitment to accessibility remains constant. We're focused on making sure innovation moves forward without leaving anyone behind. To achieve that goal, we are actively innovating how accessibility considerations can be integrated in all parts of the Product Development Lifecycle, especially in early phases like design.

Want to dig deeper? Explore SAP's existing Accessibility Design Tools and stay tuned for more!

 

References

1. World Health Organization, 2023: Fact Sheet on Blindness and Vision Impairment

entry.title: Re: Error in creating billing document in intercompany STO
entry.content:
Hello @yKim 

Thank you for the details. The error 'Tax statement item missing for tax code V0' occurs when a billing document includes a revenue line with tax code V0 sent to FI, but no output-tax condition line exists in pricing, preventing FI from creating the BSET tax line. In intercompany STO, SD tax is determined by the sales area of the supplying company, not by the PO tax code, which does not influence billing.

To reseove it, go to the billing document â†’ Pricing Analysis, ensure an output-tax condition is present, 0% is acceptable and that FI has a tax code V0 with G/L assignment. If not found, follow the next steps. KBA 3587141. If the intercompany STO master data is incomplete, follow KBA 3493622.

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Value Help in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition always res...
entry.content:
Hello @Hiromu_Masuyama 

S/4HANA  Public Cloud does not currently include a standard feature to save last-used filters or automatically apply default filters in the value help dialog. Consider this as a design limitation of the current system help.

To control what appears in value help, apply authorisation-based restrictions on business roles. Set Read to Restricted which also limits Value Help and manage permitted values like Company Code, Sales Organisation, and Country, ensuring users only see entries they are authorised to access.

What you should do

In Maintain Business Roles â†’ Restrictions: set Read and thus Value Help to Restricted, then enter the allowed organisation values for that role. This permanently limits value help lists for those users.

For demonstrations, utilise a JP-only role or user (restricted to JP company code or sales organisation alongside the Personal Value List for quick selections.

Useful SAP References

SAP Help â€“ How to Define Authorisations Using Restrictions describes restricting access by entering values into restriction fields in business roles; read restrictions flow down to Value Help SAP Help Portal-Identity and Access Management-How to Define Authorisations Based on Restrictions

SAP Learning â€“ Maintaining Business Role Restrictions (explicitly states that Read set to Restricted lets you define which data is visible, and that Value Help inherits those restrictions). SAP Learning-Maintaining Business Role Restrictions

SAP Blog â€“ How to limit filter values in SAP Fiori apps best practice: implement explicit authorizations or restrictions to control the values users can view or select SAP Community-Maintaining Business Role Restrictions

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Cancel Release in Approved purchase order
entry.content:
Hi @winpavan90 

Thank you for your question.

Consult Manage Purchase Orders & Flexible Workflow for Purchase Orders for more details.

To summarise, in public cloud, there is not Fiori app equivalent to ME29N for cancelling a purchase order release. Once a PO is approved through flexible workflow, the release cannot be directly revoked. If you need to stop a released PO, you can use the Manage Purchase Orders app to chang or block the PO, which will trigger a new workflow instance depending on your workflow configuration. Alternatively, you can design a flexible workflow to include a rejection or cancellation path if approvers need the ability to undo their approval.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to Be Linking Commercial Invoices Upload to Sales...
entry.content:
Hi @YY21 

Thank you for your question.

Consult Create Billing Documents, Billing Document & Manage Billing Documents for more details.

To summarise, in Public Cloud there is no standard app to upload commercial invoice numbers from Excel and link them to multiple sales orders. Commercial Invoices in SAP are represented by billing documents, which can be created collectively from sales orders by using the Create Billing Documents-Billing Due List app. If your requirement is to actually generate the invoices in SAP, that app is the standard solution.

If, however, you only need to register external invoice numbers managed in Excel, you have two options:

  • Use integration through the Billing Document APP to load invoice numbers from Excel into SAP and link them to sales orders, or
  • You build a Custom Business Object with Excel upload to store invoice references and map them to sales orders without creating SAP billing documents.

The right choice will depend on whether your Commercial Invoices should be financial posting in SAP or just external references.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Cancel Release in Approved purchase order
entry.content:
Hello @winpavan90 

In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, there is no dedicated â€œCancel Releaseâ€ function, and ME29N is not available. To reverse an approval, utilise one of these standard options:

There is no Cancel Release app and no ME29N.

To undo an approval, you restart Flexible Workflow by changing a field configured to trigger re-approval; the status then returns to â€œIn Approvalâ€.

Alternatively, you can block the PO (header or item) or set it for deletionâ€”these actions halt follow-up processing but do not alter the approval history.

There is no undo button in My Inbox after approval. The recommended method is to restart the workflow by making a change or blocking/cancelling to halt subsequent steps.

SAP's useful documentation

  • Flexible Workflow for Purchase Orders (Public Cloud) â€“ setup and re-evaluation on change
  • Manage Purchase Orders (App ID F0842A) â€“ edit, block/unblock, delete flags
  • My Inbox â€“ approve/reject tasks (no cancel-after-approve function)

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: In SAP S/4 Hana Public Cloud for the OSS (One Stop Sh...
entry.content:
Hello @Fabiane_Melo74 

Thank you for your question.

Consult Country wise approach for One Stop Shop in Business ByDesign & Custom Analytical Queries for more details.

To summarise, the VAT One Stop Shop Return app is currently not available for Portugal while using public cloud. The recommended approach is to extract the necessary OSS data through standard reporting and or custom CDS views.

  • The Tax Line Item app can already give you values by tax code and tax amount.
  • If you need destination country and net sales values together, you can build a Custom CDS View on I_JournalEntryItem and I_TaxJournalEntryItem and expose it through Custom Analytical Queries. This gives you a reuseable report you can filter by country, tax code, net value and tax amount.
  • Alternatively, export the CDS output to Excel and use it for the OSS filing.

For you to fully automate OSS submission in Portugal, an integration or partner add-on may be required, since the official OSS return app for Portugal has not yet been delivered by SAP.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: What Does Each Block Item Control in 'Define Reasons...
entry.content:
Hi @SatoMasayoshi 

Thank you for your question.

In summary, each checkbox in the Define Reasons for Blocking in Shipping SSCUI controls a specific sub-process of sales order and delivery processing in public cloud. For example, order blocks SO creation, DlvDueListBlock prevents the order from appearing in the Delivery Due List, Pick.Block prevents warehouse picking, and GI Block stops Post Goods Issue. The Central Delivery Block filed in the Business Partner master will always block delivery creation as a baseline, regardless of which sub-process flags you have checked, which is why you still observed blocking even when all boxes were unticked. To test the effects, you can consider using Fiori apps such as Create Sales Orders, Run Outbound Delivery Creation, Manage Outbound Deliveries and Post Goods Issue for Outbound Delivery.

Consult Blocking Sites, Manage Customer Master Data & Outbound Deliveries for more details.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Alternative Account Change Blocked in S/4HANA Cloud P...
entry.content:
Hello @nbek 

You cannot change the Alternative Account (ALTKT) on a G/L that has non-zero balances in the current or previous years. That restriction (FH007) is intentional in S/4HANA Public Cloud, and there is no override. KBA 1650435 - Error message FH007 appears in TA FS00

How to stay compliant for FY 2025 (France/PCG):

Create new G/L accounts with the required French alternative account numbers for FY SAP Help-General Ledger Accounting-G/L Account Master Data: FAQ

Transfer asset accounting account determination retirements NBV, proceeds, clearing, etc, to the new G/Ls with a valid-from date of 01.01.2025 or the start of your financial year so that all 2025 postings are allocated to the correct alternative account. Leave historical years intact, no reposting of 2024.

Reporting: Enable the Alternative Account column in statutory reports, Financial Statement â€“ Actuals, and Trial Balance. This change ensures that auditors will see the correct PCG numbers starting from 2025; earlier years will continue to display the legacy mapping..KBA 3102866 - Alternative G/L Account for G/L Account - S/4HANA Cloud

If you need the G/Ls immediately in Production, use Synchronise G/L Account Master Data after creating them in Q. SAP Help-General Ledger Accounting-Synchronise G/L Account Master Data (Two-System Landscape)

Notes

The zero-then-change-then-reverse method is not allowed for closed or audited years and is limited by Cloud governance.

SAPâ€™s recommended approach in Public Cloud is using a new G/L combined with valid-from switching in account determination. This method preserves audit history and complies with the legal change required by 2025.SAP Help General Ledger-Create and Edit Account Determination

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Enabling 'Compliance' tab in Purchase order header &...
entry.content:
Hi @AdyashaPatra 

Thank you for your question.

In public cloud, the new compliance status fields in purchase orders (Embargo Screening, Legal Control) remain Not relevant, no check unless the document is actually synchronised and updated with GTS results. In addition to enabling them in Active Checks for Purchasing Documents, you must ensure that:

  • The SAP_COM_0594 communication arrangement for Trade Compliance with GTS is active.
  • Vendors and materials are flagged as relevant for compliance in master data.
  • The background job Check Compliance for Purchasing Documents is scheduled or triggered manually through the corresponding Fiori app so that the compliance statuses are updated.

Once you have put those in place, a PO blocked in GTS will correctly reflect the block in the Compliance ab fields in S4HC.

I recommend you consult Supplier Check in Purchasing Documents,  Trade Services Compliance & https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/ee9ee0ca4c3942068ea584d2f929b5b1/0f770376bbb84c0a8e7af82d24b5c87f.html?locale=en-US&version=2508.00 for more details.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA API for A_JournalEntryItemBasic changes order...
entry.content:
Hello @litox 

Your  first row changes because your $orderby is not unique, so $stop=1 can select a different tied row when $select changes. To make the sorting consistent, include the entityâ€™s key fields or the generated ID) in both $select and $orderby,such as &$orderby=CompanyCode,FiscalYear,AccountingDocument,Ledger,AccountingDocumentItem. Even better, filter directly by the business key instead of relying on $top=1.

Check your inbox for detailed code

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: OAuth2.0 Authentication Error When Setting Up Comm. A...
entry.content:
Hi @Vynerfes 

Thank you for your question and the detailed screenshots.

I recommend you consult Setting Up a Communication System, Credentials for the OAuth 2.0 Client Creation & Electronic Invoicing in Malaysia for more details.

In summary, based on the screenshots you provided, the error message you are seeing occurs because the outbound OAuth2 configuration does not fully match what the IRBM API expects. In particular, with client credentials flow, S4HC will send grant_type=client_credentials automatically but only if the authorisation endpoint is left bland and the token endpoint is correctly set. If you include an unsupported scope or a mismatched endpoint, the token request fails with a generic OAuth error.

I recommend you check the following:

  • Leave Authorisation Endpoint blank.
  • Use only the Token Endpoint = .../connect/token.
  • Ensure Client Authorisation = Basic.
  • Only maintain scope if IRBM explicitly requires it

If IRBM requires additional non-standard fields in the token request, you must route through SAP Integration Suite to enrich the payload.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.content:
Hi Gowtham,

To grant access to SAP for Me, it is essential that both users have an active S-user ID. Administrators listed under Users & Contacts - SAP for Me are authorized to create new S-user IDs for users.  

For detailed guidance on how administrators can create or delete S-user IDs, please refer to the KBA 1271482 - How does an administrator create or delete S-user IDs? - SAP for Me

Additionally, if the users need to manage SAP support cases (e.g., creating, closing, or replying to cases), they will require specific case-related authorizations. These permissions can be assigned based on varying levels, such as CCC level, customer number level, or installation number level, depending on your organization's needs.

The required authorizations are as follows:

  • Report Technical Problem
  • Close Cases (see KBA 2646108)
  • Send Cases to SAP (see KBA 2656179)
  • Display Cases
  • Display all Cases
  • Display Cloud Data (applies to SAP Cloud products only, e.g. SuccessFactors, refer to KBA 2598170)

For further details on support case handling authorizations, you can review KBA 3383142 - Which S-user ID authorizations are required for support case handling? - SAP for Me.

If you have any additional questions or need further clarification, please let me know. I am happy to assist you further.

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Tax code rate is not displayed in Journal Entry - Cus...
entry.content:
Hello,

Please Note: because SAP only releases selected CDS views, the actual availabilities can vary by version or country.
Also: Some of the field names are inferred from SAP Help / API Hub documentation, community posts, or SAPâ€™s â€œTax Codeâ€ documentation. Always confirm in your systemâ€™s View Browser / CDS Metadata.

CDS ViewPurpose / What It RepresentsKey Fields / ColumnsNotes / Comments
I_TaxCodeMaster data for tax codes (how tax is applied)- Country - Tax Code - Tax Type - Tax Calculation Procedure - Valid-From / Valid-To - Description / TextBasic tax-code master CDS. Does not reliably include the tax rate / percentage in published versions.
(Possible) I_TaxRateType or similarMaster / condition type view that holds tax rate percentages- Tax Rate Type (ID) - Tax Percentage / Rate - Validity or Effective Date - Country / JurisdictionNot always exposed or allowed in joins. Some CDS views may expose tax percentage.
(Associated) I_TaxCodeText / text viewsText / descriptive information for tax codes- Tax Code (key) - Language - Tax Code Name / Long DescriptionHelps with descriptions. Often linked to I_TaxCode via â€œ_Textâ€ association.
(Transaction-related) I_JournalEntryItem / I_BillingDocumentItem etc.Transaction items where tax is posted- Tax Code - Amount / Base Amount / Tax Amount - Document / Company Code / CurrencyThese transactional views include tax amounts but not tax rate fields.
(If available / country-specific) â€œTax Informationâ€ CDS viewCombined view (sometimes in localized extensions)- Country - Tax Code - Tax PercentageSome localized CDS views may provide both tax code and tax percentage in one place, depending on country content delivery.

I hope this provides you some guidance.

entry.title: Re: Reverse Document Number
entry.content:
Hello @piyush_kr ,

Original Accounting Document
-The number assignment depends on the document type configuration in number ranges.
-SAP allows internal or external number assignment for original documents.
Example:
-Standard FI documents (like invoices, G/L postings) usually use internal numbers.
-Some business scenarios (like customer invoice numbers) may use external assignment if configured that way.

Reversal Document
-Always gets a new internal number automatically from its document typeâ€™s number range.
-You cannot manually assign or force it to be external.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: Levels in FSV
entry.content:
Hello @piyush_kr ,

In SAP S/4HANA, the Financial Statement Version (FSV) is structured hierarchically to represent accounts in a balance sheet or P&L.

The hierarchy in FSV can have up to 10 levels of nodes (groups / subgroups).
Level 1 â†’ Top node (e.g., Assets, Liabilities, P&L).
Level 2â€“9 â†’ Sub-nodes (e.g., Current Assets â†’ Cash â†’ Bank Accounts).
Level 10 â†’ Final level, usually the assignment of G/L accounts.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,

entry.title: Re: Entering Trading Partner in Park supplier invoice App
entry.content:
Hello @willwong 

Thank you for pointing to KBA 3362094 â€” SAP confirms that there is no Park function in that app KBA 2856664 KBA 2856664 - Create Incoming Invoices app has no park functionality - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

What is possible with S/4HANA Public Cloud

Park Supplier Invoices (LIV) facilitate parking but do not show the Trading Partner on the user interface. The preferred approach is to extract the Trading Partner from the Supplier Business Partner (bp) record, specifically by maintaining it under role FLVN00 in the BP, within Company Code â†’ Accounting Info â†’ Trading Partner. This method ensures that the value is included in accounting postings, even if it was not entered during parking. SAP Help Portal-Park Supplier Invoices

If you must key Trading Partners manually, then Create Incoming Invoices works for entry, but it cannot be parked; instead, you need to rely on Flexible Workflow for approval and controls rather than parking.

Given that, it seems there is no single app that allows both manually parking and entering a Trading Partner. Recommendation: continue using Park Supplier Invoices and ensure the Trading Partner is maintained on the vendor BP so the field is correctly populated at posting.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Optimizing Accessibility for Limited Mobility
entry.content:
Challenges affecting strength, dexterity, or fine motor control impact a wide range of people, with data showing significant prevalence among certain groups â€”for example, approximately 35% of adults experience mobility limitations by age 70[1]. However, designing for accessibility isn't just for people with permanent conditions. It also benefits anyone dealing with temporary or situational conditions that affect everyday life, like having a sprained wrist, using a device one-handed while carrying groceries, or trying to input information on a mobile device while riding on a bumpy road.

A woman with glasses smiles with her arms crossed. Text reads: â€œAround 35% of adults have mobility limitations by age 70. SAP designs for those with limited mobility. Check out our tips for focus order, shortcuts, motion alternatives and more!â€

Design For Accessibility Is Design For Everyone

When we design with accessibility in mind, we're not just checking a box, we're creating digital experiences that are easier to use for everyone. Making interaction easier and tasks more achievable doesn't just help some users; it improves product quality across the board.

5 Tips to Optimize Accessibility for Those With Limited Mobility

Supporting users with limited mobility means designing for a broad range of abilities, from permanent conditions to temporary or situational mobility challenges. The guidance in SAP's Accessibility Design Tools, Second Edition, and the Inclusive Research Handbook helps turn this awareness into practical steps. With these resources in mind, here are five tips to help you get started:

1. Keyboard Functionality

  • Ensure all functionality is accessible via keyboard, such as Tab to navigate and Enter/Space to interact.
  • Maintain a logical tab order and ensure that users can navigate out of elements like pop-ups or forms with their keyboard.
  • Why? Limited mobility can make using a mouse difficult, especially when targeting small buttons or moving the cursor quickly across the screen, often causing strain and frequent errors.

2. Touch Target

  • Design buttons and interactive elements with a minimum touch target of 44Ã—44 px.
  • Increase spacing between adjacent clickable items to reduce accidental activation.
  • Why? Small clickable areas can be difficult to activate accurately. This can result in missed or accidental clicks, especially for people using a touchscreen or anyone with difficulty with precise mouse control.

3. On-screen Buttons

  • For any action that requires a complex touch gesture, such as swiping or pinching, always provide a simple on-screen button that performs the same function.
  • Why? Multi-step gestures like pinch-to-zoom, swipe, long-press, and complex keyboard shortcuts such as Ctrl + Alt + Shift can be physically difficult or impossible for some users.

4. Shortcuts and Customizable Settings

  • Prioritize task efficiency by minimizing the number of steps required to complete tasks.
  • To reduce user effort, provide shortcuts and customizable settings, such as skip links or collapsible sections.
  • Why? Requiring long navigation paths or excessive interactions increases physical effort and can cause fatigue, particularly during repetitive or extended use.

5. Focus Indicators

  • Always provide clear, high-contrast focus indicators for all interactive elements.
  • Ensure the focus order is logical and predictable.
  • Why? Without a visible focus, keyboard users often cannot easily track their position on the page. This makes navigation difficult and increases the risk of activating the wrong element.

How SAP Designs with Accessibility in Mind

Technology keeps changing, but our commitment to Accessibility remains constant. We're focused on ensuring innovation moves forward without leaving anyone behind. To achieve that goal, we are actively innovating how accessibility considerations can be integrated in all parts of the Product Development Lifecycle, especially in early phases like design.

Want to dig deeper? Explore SAP's Accessibility Design Tools, Second Edition

 

References:

1. Frontiers in Physiology. (2020). Mobility in older community-dwelling persons: A narrative review. Frontiers in Physiology, 11, 881.

Probably you have searched the SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library, and none of these transactions are listed. Probably they were flagged as obsolete. Check the SAP notes.

2471733 - Error CKMLAVR099 when accessing transaction: CKMH, CKMI in S4HANA - SAP for Me: the conclusion is that CKMH and CKMI are obsolete because the logic has dramatically changed. See Troubleshooting Guide Material Ledger | SAP Help Portal.

3313290 - Disable transactions CKMF, CKMG and CKMJ - SAP for Me: replaced with CKMF_RUN, CKMG_RUN and CKMJ_RUN.

KBC6, KBC7: no information so still valid.

No Fiori Apps for all of them.

entry.title: Re: PCR for PF Calculation Using Processed Basic
entry.content:
You did not mention for what Country, but it may not be important for this calculation.  

In your Payroll Schema, after PCR Z023, you could add Function PRINT with 1st parameter VAR so that you could see what is contained in the Variables Table when you do Payroll with the "Display Log" box checked and be able to confirm that the temporary variable BVER exists with the appropriate Amount (personnaly, I would have put Operation ADDWT&BVER before ADDWTE* just to make sure that it did not disapear after ADDCU).

Based on the portion of RT that you posted, WT 1101 has ESG * while WT 1000 has ESG 3 

and it could have been useful to see those WTs in the Input Table to PCR Z023 , but in it you process WT 1000 in ESG * (and you did not show what happens in ESG 3)  while you did not show what Operations are used for the WTs with ESG * that fall under WT **** (such as WT 1101)

and in pcr ZREC you process WT 1101 in ESG 3 instead of ESG * 

In PCR Z023, try processing WT 1000 under ESG 3, and in PCR ZREC, try processing WT 1101 under ESG *

entry.title: Re: PCR for PF Calculation Using Processed Basic
entry.content:
Note that if Function PRINT with 1st parameter VAR works in your Country's Payroll, you could add it in many places in your Payroll Schema to help you see the temporary variables that exist before or after certains PCRs. 

 

When I add a new PCR to our Payroll Schema, I often insert it before a PCR that will use Temporary Variable and after a PCR that will create a Temporary Variable just to be able to better see the Inputs and Outputs when I test my new PCR (usually a Simulation of Payroll with the "Display Log" box checked), and can delete them (the Functions PRINT I just added) before releasing my transport, bu.t over the years we have left a few of them throughout our Payroll Schema

Modules clÃ©s : PP (Production Planning), MM (Materials Management), QM (Quality Management), WM/EWM (Warehouse Management).

Distribution & retail (ex. : Marjane, Carrefour, Labelâ€™Vie)

TÃ©lÃ©coms (ex. : Maroc Telecom, Orange, Inwi)

Secteur public et Ã©ducation (ex. : UniversitÃ©s, administrations, hÃ´pitaux)

Objectif : suivre les budgets, amÃ©liorer la gestion des ressources humaines et fluidifier les achats publics.

Avec SAP S/4HANA, ces modules deviennent encore plus puissants grÃ¢ce aux interfaces Fiori et aux capacitÃ©s analytiques en temps rÃ©el. Le choix ne se limite donc pas aux besoins actuels, mais doit aussi anticiper les Ã©volutions futures de lâ€™entreprise et de son secteur.

entry.title: Les donnÃ©es de base dans SAP MM S/4HANA : le socle de toute la gestion des achats et des stocks
entry.content:
1. DÃ©finition et rÃ´le des donnÃ©es de base

Les donnÃ©es de base (ou Master Data) regroupent toutes les informations essentielles et permanentes nÃ©cessaires aux processus du module MM.
Elles sont partagÃ©es entre plusieurs modules afin dâ€™assurer lâ€™intÃ©gration et la cohÃ©rence des donnÃ©es au sein du systÃ¨me SAP.

Les principales donnÃ©es de base dans SAP MM sont :

La fiche article (Material Master) : contient toutes les informations liÃ©es Ã  un produit ou un service (type dâ€™article, unitÃ© de mesure, groupe dâ€™achat, valeur, etc.).

La fiche fournisseur (Vendor Master) : regroupe les informations administratives, comptables et dâ€™achat sur les partenaires externes.

La fiche info-achat (Purchasing Info Record) : Ã©tablit le lien entre un article et un fournisseur.

Les conditions dâ€™achat (Conditions de prix) : dÃ©finissent les rÃ¨gles de tarification et les remises appliquÃ©es aux achats.

 

Ces donnÃ©es permettent Ã  SAP de proposer automatiquement les bonnes informations lors de la crÃ©ation dâ€™une demande ou dâ€™une commande dâ€™achat.

 

 2. Configuration et structure des donnÃ©es de base

Chaque donnÃ©e de base est configurÃ©e selon la structure organisationnelle de lâ€™entreprise :

La fiche article est dÃ©finie par centre et par magasin, car les informations peuvent varier dâ€™un site Ã  un autre.

La fiche fournisseur est crÃ©Ã©e au niveau du code sociÃ©tÃ© et du domaine dâ€™achat, afin de diffÃ©rencier les conditions comptables et logistiques.

Dans le Customizing (SPRO), la configuration des donnÃ©es de base inclut notamment :

La dÃ©finition des types dâ€™articles (ROH, FERT, HAWA, etc.)

Les types de fournisseurs et les groupes de comptes

La configuration des vues article selon les besoins mÃ©tier (achat, comptabilitÃ©, planification, etc.)

Cette configuration garantit une cohÃ©rence entre les dÃ©partements et un contrÃ´le des autorisations dâ€™accÃ¨s.

 

 3. Utilisation dans les processus mÃ©tiers

Les donnÃ©es de base interviennent Ã  chaque Ã©tape du cycle Procure-to-Pay (P2P) :

Lors de la crÃ©ation dâ€™une demande dâ€™achat, les donnÃ©es article et fournisseur dÃ©terminent les valeurs par dÃ©faut.

Dans la commande dâ€™achat, la fiche info-achat propose automatiquement le dernier prix nÃ©gociÃ©.

Lors de la rÃ©ception de marchandises, les donnÃ©es article dÃ©finissent les types de mouvement et la valorisation.

Lors de la facturation, les donnÃ©es fournisseur assurent la correspondance avec les informations comptables.

 

Ainsi, une donnÃ©e de base mal configurÃ©e peut impacter toute la chaÃ®ne logistique, provoquer des erreurs de prix, des blocages de factures, ou encore une mauvaise Ã©valuation de stock.

 

 4. Impact sur lâ€™intÃ©gration inter-modules

Les donnÃ©es de base du module MM sont partagÃ©es avec dâ€™autres modules SAP :

Avec FI (Finance) pour lâ€™Ã©valuation et la comptabilisation des stocks et factures.

Avec SD (Sales & Distribution) pour la gestion des ventes et des livraisons.

Avec PP (Production Planning) pour lâ€™approvisionnement des composants.

Cette intÃ©gration permet Ã  SAP de fonctionner comme un systÃ¨me unique oÃ¹ une donnÃ©e est crÃ©Ã©e une seule fois mais utilisÃ©e partout.

 

 5. Bonnes pratiques et recommandations

Mettre en place une gouvernance des donnÃ©es : rÃ´les clairs pour la crÃ©ation et la validation.

Utiliser la transaction MM01/MM02/MM03 pour la gestion de la fiche article.

ContrÃ´ler les donnÃ©es obligatoires et les champs de saisie via la configuration dans SPRO.

Former les utilisateurs sur la logique des vues et des niveaux organisationnels.

VÃ©rifier rÃ©guliÃ¨rement la qualitÃ© et la cohÃ©rence des donnÃ©es (dÃ©doublons, champs vides, erreurs de codification).

 

 Conclusion

Les donnÃ©es de base dans SAP MM S/4HANA ne sont pas de simples fichiers administratifs : elles reprÃ©sentent lâ€™intelligence du systÃ¨me. Leur bonne configuration garantit la fluiditÃ© des processus, la fiabilitÃ© des analyses, et la rÃ©ussite de lâ€™intÃ©gration entre les modules SAP.
